Mid Continent Nail Corporation produces half the nails made in the United States at its factory in southeast Missouri.
On June 1, President Trump imposed new tariffs on steel imports.
In the following two weeks, Mid Continent's sales went down by half, causing over 100 workers to lose their jobs.
Chris Pratt is Mid Continent's operations general manager, and he joins us from his home in Poplar Bluff, Mo.
Thank you for coming on the program, sir.
Thank you for having me.
I appreciate it.
What exactly is a 232 tariff?
A 232 tariff is a tariff that is imposed by the president.
He imposed that tariff on steel and aluminum.
Mr.
Pratt, why did the new tariffs hurt your company's sales so badly?

Well, Section 232 tariffs only affect steel, not finished goods, so when we tried to pass on that 25 percent, which - our customers, in the two-week period, canceled 50 percent of their orders for June because they could buy import nails that are not subject to the 232 tariff.
You know, right now, we're fighting 232 tariffs imposed by our own president, which, in turn, has allowed steel producers to raise their price 30 percent, as well.
I'm sorry.
Did you say that American steelmakers are increasing their prices by 30 percent?
That's correct.
Why?
Because they can.
When import supply is eliminated, that just gave them the ability to raise their price 25 percent, and they capitalized on it and raised it even more.
Do you think tariffs make the United States better off, even if they hurt your company's bottom line?
Well, I think some tariffs do.
I think this is a misguided policy.
It was not thought out well.
Of course, it helps the big steel companies, but it's going to affect all the downstream manufacturing jobs.
You know, we're asking for help for them to grant our exclusions that we filed.
And it can be approved by President Trump just by signing the exclusion, and that's what we're asking him to do.
Mr.
Pratt, will the people who lost their jobs at Mid Continent be able to find jobs elsewhere?
It will be tough in our area.
I mean, it's an area of 17,000 people.
We're the second-largest employer in the area, employing over 500 at one time.
And it will be tough for them to find other jobs.
In the 2016 election, Donald Trump got 80 percent of the vote in Poplar Bluff and in surrounding counties.
Has local support for President Trump changed because of what is happening to your company?

Several of our employees have been interviewed by different media groups, and, you know, most of those employees have said that they voted for Trump and they still support Trump, but they want him to see what's going on, look at what he's doing to our company, to them, to the individual and to all the ancillary suppliers that we have, as well.
I think they still support him at this point.
But if it gets to the point where they lose their jobs, I think the support in our area is going to diminish.

My humble plan was to become a hero of the environmental movement.

What I remember, I used to go to the birds' house.
My dad, like all the time, whenever he wanted, because he usually - in the morning he wake up early and he went to birds' house and he feed the birds.

I was about seven or eight years old when the war started.

And I knew it was war because when you go outside, it's so quiet, like you can't see any human being as you feel like there's nobody lives in the country because everyone is like hiding inside their house.
All we could hear was the bomb explode or we could hear the planes that they drop bomb.
You could hear people crying and you know that somebody got killed or something.
As the war got worse, we would hide in the basement.
It didn't have any windows or any door to go to it.
It was just kind of like a big - a hole that you just walk into it.
My poor father still went outside.
My mom told him a lot of times, do no go to the birds' house, but she couldn't stop him.
Nobody could stop my dad from going to the birds' house.
He loved the birds like as if they were his own child.
It was one day - that day changed everything.
It was so quiet and peaceful.
It felt like there was no war going on in the country.
And my dad, that day in the morning he looked so calm and quiet, really different.
He wanted to go to his work.
And I would just cry, run after him and say, please, please take me.
But he was like, no, I will come back.
And I asked him if he would bring me gum.
And he was like, sure.
And he just walked away.
Then 15 or 20 minutes later we heard a bomb explosion.
And then we heard another bomb explosion.
And then my neighbor was screaming at us and telling us to get in the basement.

And I heard like the guys - like all the neighbors and they start coming inside the house.
And they were like really nervous.
And one of them was asking for me.
He was keep calling my name and saying, I want to find your mom.
